abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Education Project in Botswana
            was achieved. In close cooperation with, and assisted by the
            Bank, the Government through its various entities played a
            very positive role in the preparation of the project, even
            if preparation did not always go into such details as would
            be needed eventually for speedy project implementation. It
            would appear that the one weakness of the Bank relative to
            this project was in the project design. For the benefit of
            future Bank projects in education in Botswana, it is to be
            hoped that the close and intensive working relationship
            between the Bank on the one hand, and the Government on the
            other, could be maintained even under the auspices of the
            re-organization of the Bank.

docna.cdata!:
Botswana - Second Education Project : Loan
            1828 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Botswana - Second Education
            Project : Loan 1828 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Education Project will expand
            and improve the network of junior secondary schools,
            increase rural vocational training and provide training for
            civil servants and public sector personnel. Major components
            include: (a) providing of classrooms, science facilities,
            offices and site work for about 11 community junior
            secondary schools, (b) constructing about 7 new community
            junior secondary schools, (c) assisting about 7 youth
            brigade centers and 9 agriculture brigades, (d) expanding
            the facilities at the Botswana Training Center and the
            Institute of Development Management, and (e) providing
            technical assistance for specialist services in the Project
            Implementation Unit. The project will help Botswana meet its
            future work force requirements by expanding enrollments at
            the junior secondary level and in institutions providing
            vocational, civil service and management training. The
            project's risk involve the adequate provision of junior
            secondary school teachers, particularly in mathematics and
            sciences, and possible difficulties in the formation and
            operation of the agricultural brigades.
